messages.message: I’ve been testing the new dynamic opacity adjustments for the anomaly overlays. The results look promising so far!

replies.message: That’s great to hear, Maria. Were there any unexpected edge cases?
Not yet, but I want to run a few more tests in low-light conditions to be sure.

messages.message: Just a heads-up: I added a new section to the deployment checklist on Notion for monitoring real-time anomalies. Please review: https://notion.nvidia.com/retail-safety/real-time-monitoring.

replies.message: Thanks, James. I’ll cross-check it with our QA processes.
I’ve added a few notes about latency thresholds. Let me know if they align with your expectations.

messages.message: I’m finalizing the parameter adjustments for the Kalman filter. Should we prioritize these changes for the next sprint?

replies.message: Yes, let’s include them. Reducing the jitter in bounding boxes is a priority.
Agreed. This is one of the most noticeable issues during customer trials.

messages.message: Do we have a timeline for integrating the fallback mechanisms into the Dallas deployment pipeline?

replies.message: I’m estimating we can complete this by the end of the week, assuming no major blockers.
Let’s schedule a code review on Friday to ensure everything’s in place.

messages.message: I’ve been looking at ways to improve anomaly labeling accuracy. Has anyone considered using weighted loss functions?

replies.message: Interesting idea. We could weigh anomalies differently based on their criticality levels.
That approach could also help with edge cases like overlapping anomalies.

messages.message: Has anyone gotten feedback from QA on the updated test cases for inconsistent lighting conditions?

replies.message: Yes, they flagged a few scenarios where the detection fails completely. I’ll share the detailed report shortly.
We should prioritize fixing those before expanding the deployment.
